s.text: They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.

They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.

They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.

They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.

They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.

They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.

They moved from an Apple to Windows audience in their early days without a blink; they moved from a gated service to one where the Web was nearly co-opted into AOL; they went from hourly to unlimited without a look back--this is a company that is not tethered to anything except that which works.
That is due, in large part, to the personality of Steve Case, who is indeed a smart and clever guy and someone I would not often bet against.
That is due, in large part, to the personality of Steve Case, who is indeed a smart and clever guy and someone I would not often bet against.
That is due, in large part, to the personality of Steve Case, who is indeed a smart and clever guy and someone I would not often bet against.
Like Andy Serwer--also an old friend from graduate school, where he also dated my roommate--I think free Internet access makes a lot of sense.
But in the match-up between AOL and Microsoft--at least in the online space--the giant from Redmond has proved time and again to be the decidedly weaker player.

This was a group of people that had been born into near-bankruptcy and lived its formative years in a near-constant state of chaos.
As you surely know from our stellar stories in the WSJ , Microsoft has been making a lot of noises in this direction of late and those strategies are clearly aimed at AOL.
So, the free access trend seems to me to be another assault at the gates of Steve Case that will probably not kill them.
His hard shell, in fact, was one of the problems I had when writing my book.
